reasoning: The critique targets an implicit modeling choice in the economist/CES framing (progress as a function of compute K and cognitive labor L), arguing that a third input—novel data, potentially from the physical world—could be a separate hard bottleneck. If true, this would undercut the paper’s practical conclusion that compute bottlenecks likely won’t slow an SIE until late stages, but it doesn’t directly refute the paper’s main claim about compute–labor substitutability; it instead adds an alternative bottleneck. Hence moderate centrality. The argument is plausible but underdeveloped: it doesn’t establish that frontier AI R&D during an SIE would actually be constrained by scarce real-world data (vs. reusing existing data, synthetic data, self-play, improved inference/architecture, better evaluation, etc.), nor that such data is non-substitutable in the relevant margin. Some claims are overstated (e.g., implying physical-world data is required for ‘the next token’ of progress, or that simulation would require “infinite compute”). Still, it correctly notes the omission and a real possible constraint. Clear, focused, and with little extraneous material.
title: Data as a binding constraint is absent from the production function
